Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tamborine Yeah, I just started reading on all of this. Are you saying that a prostatectomy may not be an option in some cases? Do you mean if it has metastatiszed or what? Yes it can be a minefield and not everything you read means it will happen to you. Given your stats ( and you don't have any yet ) you may have a number of options in regard to treatment, Radiation, surgery, seeds they all have their pros and cons. As a rule of thumb the earlier PC is caught the more choice you have.. which in a way is a curse as you have to make the choice and generally none of us are medical practitioners to know what is best. If it has metastasized, which just by your comments is unlikely, it will reduce or change the treatment. My guess is that this is something which should be put aside for now as a conversation untill your results are in. The comments above about your PSA level ring true, but it is a little alarming that they have spiked, mine went from 2.5 year on year to 4.2 and I was diagnosed post biopsy. However I went on 2 rounds of anti biotics to rule out infection over a 3 month period. This is potentailly where you should be now.. ruling out the irregularity

Posts.Title: Why Not a Prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Welcome Tamborine, Quite a number of questions in there, I have to guess you are early into the learning curve. The Biopsy is probably the best way of advancing the answers to your questions, given your PSA is elevated this is a flag to say something is not right and needs further investigation. The Biopsy is not perfect however they have improved its application and it has a pretty good hit rate. In my case it painted a very positive picture however post op pathology showed is was much worse. For a PC to metastasize that quickly post biopsy means it was well underway already, they will get you scanned if the biopsy comes back positive anyway. As for your key question why not?, it generally is not a case of why not, more a case of what are my options, what are the impacts/ side effects and have I done all I can to assure myself that what I am being told is accurate.

Fran 7-8 weeks seems to be the sweet spot, best I have felt and almost as active. Still get very tired in the evenings but that keeps improving.

Posts.Title: Why Not a Prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Hey Mr Mac, Welcome and thanks for your profile. I am only 3 weeks out and have the whole package at the moment so can't offer you insights except that this is a pretty big operation and things take time. The recommendation is you should not get back into any heavy training routine untill the 6 week mark, if this is the case for you then it has been only 2 weeks so be gentle with yourself. If you started earlier then potentially you are delaying your recovery, it is not like sit up where the more you do the better. If it helps I am a gym nut and been doing it for 25 years, I have now stopped everything except walking and feel as you do ( except shortness of breath). Just as an aside it may be worth going back and having your lungs tested, if your recovery has not regained your lung capacity it may well be you are not getting enough oxygen through your system wich affects all those symptoms you have outlined

Posts.Title: 2 months out

Posts.Content: Big breath mate, I was running at 2.5 from 40 through to 45, the name of the game is slow growth, your numbers seem to indicate you are within range for your age. I was getting my PSA tested every year or 2 with a 2.5 level and not even thinking about it. What tipped it was when it jumped to 4.2, then it was game on.. but the good thing is I had a trend line.. so my humble opinion is not to be too concerned and book the next test when they suggest

Posts.Title: 2 months out

Posts.Content: As soon as the catheter came out, it is not there to repair nerve damage it is there to keep oxygenated blood moving to the penis. The nerves are in a state of shock and will take their own merry time to right themselves. Think of it like sleeping on your arm and waking up to find it is all floppy and useless, blood starts to flow back in and the nerves recover from the shock and after a while it rights itself . Same thing except there has been trauma to the area and takes longer to recover. The key however is to keep good blood running through the area or scar tissue builds up and inhibits the recovery. The tablets are there for that purpose, originally Viagra was developed for heart condition patients to perform the same function on the heart muscle, generally blokes with heart conditions have ED and after taking viagra for their hearts their erections returned Nice side effect
Posts.Title: How long after surgery did you take viagra/cialis

Posts.Content: ahh sorry Brave did not read your post that way.. my understanding it is not a lifetime affair if you return to an adequate level of operation
Posts.Title: How long after surgery did you take viagra/cialis

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by azsunshine My understanding is it has nothing to do with healing the nerves. That is simply time. The purpose of Cialis,Viagra and Levitra is to keep blood flow going into the penis so the tissue does not atrophy and die wihile waiting for the nerves to heal. That therapeutic dose for blood flow is low and shouldn't have side effects. Hubby takes 2.5mgs every night. Night time is best so it's strength is strongest and simulates nighttime erections. Yep thats exactly how I understand it.. I am on 5mg a day of cialis and 100 mg viagra once a week

Posts.Title: New Member with Questions and some observations

Posts.Content: Yes but he was German which explains it... A young couple adopt a German baby. He was a perfectly normal except for the fact he never spoke a word. They had him tested in every different way to find out what was wrong but nothing came up until one day aged five after lunch he says, "This strudel is tepid." His parents are completely amazed. "What's been wrong? How can you talk? Why haven't you spoken before?" The boy turned to the parents and slowly replies, "Until now, everything has been satisfactory." I get it, the 2 things I think I could have done without was 1) Choice 2) knowledge...ignorance is bliss as you just have to follow the bouncing ball. Brave, just keep on keeping on try not to get too down
Posts.Title: I absolutely Hate this

Posts.Content: Great to hear mate, glad to hear the dramas are all sorted now and the recovery process can begin. Keep us up to speed with the implant sugery
Posts.Title: Dont even know where to start

Posts.Content: Hi, Sounds like you are stressing, sorry that it is keeping you awake at night but just to balance out the concerns lets look at what is fact. 2.14 is not that bad for your age, I am 46 and for 5 years running 2.5 psa levels . This gave the Dr a reason to perform a DRE but there was nothing. Only when it jumped to 4.2 did alarm bells start ringing and I had the full biopsy and subsequent diagnosis. Given the location of the prostate it is entirely possible that all those other health issues are causing some of the symptoms you talk about. Personally I would rule them all out first before chasing the cancer route, and even in the worse case it is then be assured you have probably found it so early it is curable.

AgeInfo.Phrase: for your age  I am 46 and for 5 years running

Posts.Content: Hey Am Welcome to this corner of the net, I see you are trying to educate yourself and support your partner, it is a very very important role. I have no doubt that your man is quietly very concerned himself and your support will be welcomed. It is not the end of your relationship and your approach will serve to strengthen it. It will result in a change to your sex life but this as many will tell you is not a backward step just different. I would suggest your reassurance that the relationship is greater than just one component will be met with relief. All of us men fear the change but all will tell you we adjust and a lot of that is down to our partners. Keep asking questions and help him through the journey. Best wishes

Posts.Title: How to give support, what to expect and ask about Prostrate issues?

Posts.Content: I went and saw a dietitian that was associated with the PT team at the hospital prior to surgery, she never promoted an increase in fibre just a balanced diet. But also recommended a range of foods that assist in good nutrition as well as processing.. I was confused about bowel movements post op as you generally "cleared out" prior, I was passing wind within a day and if you have a soft diet and clean foods all goes well.. Never increased fibre at all
Posts.Title: "Plenty of Fiber"

Posts.Content: Hey September, for me the surgery was 4 hours and the recovery room stay an hour ( I am not a sleeper, you are a long time dead ) The problem is the long wait to get in, I was at the hospital at 1:30pm and finally got to surgery at 4:30pm. My wife wanted to stay but I already set it up so my friends would ring her after 2 hours and send her home. We are only 10 minutes from the hospital, just get the hospital to ring you when he gets out of surgery and you can make your way down. Chances are he is not going to be in any condition to see you even when he wakes up anyway.
Posts.Title: How long is surgery?

Posts.Content: Back at ya Chuck.. thanks for being there through my journey, your kind words and support contributed significantly. Here in OZ Christmas day is almost at an end so hope yours is a good one. Here is to everyone else who is on the same road and at either end, to good health and stay positive because in the end it is all we really have. Bob
Posts.Title: Wishing Everyone a Merry Christmas!

Posts.Content: Very sorry you are here and such a sad tale, the coffee and beer are probably the 2 worst contributors to leakage. The coffee is a stumlant and will irritate the bladder causing control issues, beer is the reverse it is a relaxant and diaretic so it relaxes the bladder and the pelvic floor muscles causing high levels of leakage. I am down to 1 pad a day and it generally is in use from 4- 9 when I am tired. I agree it sounds like you hubby has more emotional and mental challenges, I stopped beer and coffee for nearly 2 months and then when reintroduced at very low quantities Have you taken him back to the doc as I think there are other options available but at 3 months there is still the expectations that there will be issues. I might suggest that you contact a depression management service because until there is motivation to help one self the physical aspects will continue to persist

Chances are he is not going to be in any condition to see you even when he wakes up anyway.

Posts.Title: 55 year old newbie wants to thank you all!

Posts.Content: To be honest they are annoying but not that bad, here is my list of tips ( pardon the pun) 1. Don't throw up whilst it is in.. I speak from experience 2. Ask for a sticky support on your leg for the tube not velcro strap 3. At night plug in the overnight bag and put it in a bucket don't use the leg bag 4. Don't throw up whilst it is in 5. Empty it often 6. In the shower put a small plastic chair or shelf to put the bag on so the straps don't get wet 7. Don't worry about it being taken out, it is 2 seconds of discomfort not pain 8. Don't throw up whilst it is in I didn't have any real issues with managing it, my "tip" got a little uncomfortable but all bearable.

Posts.Title: Radiation vs Surgery

Posts.Content: Powderfinger, Sorry I forgot to say that I am now 8 days post surgery. Brachy is still the second most applied therapy, I was offered cryo but this is still considered experimental and I am just too young in the scheme of things to be part of the experiment. Don't apologise for the way you feel, I recollect that my first reaction was "you are kidding right?, i am at my prime, spent all this time mastering the technique and you are suggesting I should pay someone to take it away " ... but over the coming weeks you thinking is going to change as you realise that you have cancer , the big C and possibly the sneakiest of the lot. It is very slow growing and doesn't affect how you feel yet it can affect so much. The next mental step is you may have incontinence, now this is a major inconvenience, not sure what work you do but if you are a bus driver or long haul truck drive you are not going to like this at all.. The radio therapist I went to see suggested that he treated Football Coaches cause they didn't want to be packing down with a team of 20 year olds and leaking.. Once you start appreciating that in the scheme of things your ability to enjoy sex is the lowest of the priorities you can understand why the list that highlander put forward is the way the Doctors approach it. Anyway you are very early in the journey and we all have been there and it makes you feel like crap, however you do adjust your thinking though it never lessens the concern you have for retention of your favourite activity. Get past the first 2 and then realise that there are options to treat that and even those with little to work with still manage to make the most of it. As I started out saying, I have just had surgery and it appears by the reports I will eventually regain most of my pre operative function, however right now I got nuthin and I am a leaky boat. Coming from a fit and active perspective and enjoying 3 times a week the affections of my better half this is tough going. But regardless I don't have cancer anymore, and as my Surgeon says.. " you will live to see your grand children grow up"
Posts.Title: New member, just diagnosed.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago Lots of people go for surgery with the idea that it provides a greater chance of total cure. I do not think there is much data to back that up comparing it to other options. . There is, mainly because historically surgery has been performed for about 25-30 years where Bracky only has about 15. In a decade or so the stats will tell you the story if Bracky is as good as surgery for longevity. Don't get me wrong, if bracky had 25 years of proven track record it would have been my preference.

Posts.Title: Thankyou to everybody here and can I join your club please

Posts.Content: Hey Powderfinger, Sad story , sorry you are here, was in your headspace in March but things are on the mend so not as down or scared anymore. I did the whole tour of duty of all the specialists to get a bead on what was the best approach. It appears quite overwhelming to deal with the fact you hve PC little lone having bloody options. The decision is one you need to make on your own based on what your priorities are, I am over a decade younger than you and all those things that concern you were magnified given the stage of life I am at.. Anyway here is what I learnt, the Surgeon say cut it out, it is what he does, Quote "30 years of gold standard proof that it is the most effective way of dealing with the cancer" I say sounds good , what are the side effects?, he says continence and ED depending on how advanced your condition is, your age and general health. At this point I am hating everything I am being told, so in a denial state I go and speak to other Urologists and Radio therapists, this is a good thing because it counter balances what you know and what you have been told. In the end the Radio therapist says "at your age i would recommend the surgery as the history for radio therapy is not as long as surgery and you need more years" His cut off was 50 for performing the procedure and I was just too young in his books.' Now the side effects from brachy initially are much lower and invasive than surgery and you get to retain most of your function, what you need to be understanding is that longer term you have a higher potential for your continence and erectile function to be impacted given that the radioactivity first kills the disease then starts a slow demise of your prostate then potentially surrounding soft tissue. The gamble is your age and whatever might get you in the end is ahead of all that. Now having been graphical about all this it is just what the specialists explained to me, I am no Dr just a patient. Given what I was told the brachy seems to have some merit given your age and the stats that you have listed in your sig. I would suggest you keep exploring the options till you are sure about the proposed approach. The key right now is to come to terms and become at peace with your decision rather than the end game which we all go to straight away. Keep talking, it helps a lot, most on here have difficult stories but want to share and assist. You are in the right place, keep reading but kep in mind everyone is different and there is only one wrong answer ... Do nothing

AgeInfo.Phrase: years  His cut off was 50 for performing the procedure and

Posts.Title: 3 Weeks post-op + path report

Posts.Content: Walt, It was extremely important to me but longevity was heavy weight to carry given my youngest is only 13, I sort of figured I wanted to see his grandkids more than wild monkey sex.. which put hings quickly into perspective not importance
Posts.Title: Can your sex life really get back to normal?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walt_Green well, sure. but, if there are other options, as far as treating, it's a factor then. for me it is, for sure. if you are within AS guidelines, and have a passionate sex life with your wife, I think you are crazy to treat. But, that's just me. I'll trade quality now, for wheel-chair time later. they can prop up a picture of me at that time. Walt (EDIT: my youngest is 13 as well. I am 51. FYI). I just turned 47 so close on your coat tails.. I reckon old age is a bitch to start with so to compound it with cancer was not appealing. Anyway we will see how it fairs in 18 months when I am closer to the prescribed recovery time, I also might add the missus is keen to get things back so puts a lot more effort in

Posts.Title: Can your sex life really get back to normal?

Posts.Content: Hey gang, Having now reached 7 weeks since surgery I was expecting to be cartwheeling about the place with only the side effects of ED and continence to concern myself with. However I am struggling to get back into my work regime, being an office worker and reading about many here in construction I am thinking I am softer than I thought. I eased myself back into work 3 weeks ago, firstly with a couple of half days then 4 half days last week and then this week I figured time to go the full hog. I made it to Wednesday this week doing full days and crashed and burned on Thursday at midday and was a wreck yesterday. Today I am starting to feel normal again.. What should the expectation about recovery to normal operating levels be, am I over doing it? Just to give a clear picture, I am up at 5 - 5:30 each day, I trave an hour or so by car and train to the city each day, normally it is a 10 hour day but I have been keeping that to 8 hours and then return trip. Figured I should be shooting the lights out by now.. what have others experienced in this regard
Posts.Title: Post Op recovery, what is the real time

Posts.Content: Thanks all for the feedback, I was concerned that I should be back to normal well and truly, seems to be a mix but tending towards what I am currently experiencing so I don't feel "soft" anymore,,, enough of that in the other department Only 5 weeks till I go on a cruise, should be hardened up by then .. geez the gags just keep coming
Posts.Title: Post Op recovery, what is the real time

Posts.Content: Thanks guys, nice to have some feedback with personal experience.. will get the info and see what you think.. OK the results are in GS seems to be 3+4 =7 Staging is not stated but type is Adenocarcinoma, NOS, acinar Right Apex small sections of adenocarcinoma, Gleason Score 3+3=6, present in 1 of 2 cores involving 2% of the core. There is a seperate PIN Right Mid. Sections show focal PIN in one of the cores Right Base. Nothing Left Apex . Sections show adenocarcinoma, Gleason Score 3+4=7, present in the largest of the 3 cores and involving 30% of that core Left mid. Nothing Left Base. nothing %High Grade 4/5 10% 2 cores out of 13 affected. Thats all the info I have at the moment

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Greetings, My name is Bob and I am 46 and 2 days ago was told that I have prostate Cancer. This as most will already know be a bit of a shock with no history in the family and in excellent health. The initial flag went up after a routine health check the company has in place and my PSA score jumped from a consistent 2.5 over some years to 4. I subsequently had the usual anti biotics and 6 weeks later retested with a drop to 3.8. The Doctor suggested a Biopsy but also the Urine test which came back inconclusive so had to undertake the Biopsy.. seems I have a Gleason score of 7 which says I have Cancer. Yesterday went for all the scans which will go back to the Doc and I guess the options will be narrow.. Hope to learn a bit more on this forum and with any luck not feel as worried as I currently do..

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: gsteve A constant concern for me also, I posted a link to a very good lecture on rehabilitation in the ED thread. I am just hitting the 3 month mark and having some progress with cialis and viagra but not "stuffable" for any length of time as such. My result is heartening at the 3 month mark and I dont expect much as I do think it is going to be a 12-18 month journey to really get a handle on what to expect. My partner is very helpful in the rehabilitation so it takes some of the mntal challenge out of it which interesting enough can affect it dramatically. As the lecture outlines that adrenalin can restrict the ability to have a decent erection and this can be brought on by anxiety. I am seeing how the next few weeks go as improvements are rewarding with the tablets but I might go the injection route on my return as I have my 3 month blood test checkup

I just turned 47 so close on your coat tails.. I reckon old age is a bitch to start with so to compound it with cancer was not appealing. Anyway we will see how it fairs in 18 months when I am closer to the prescribed recovery time, I also might add the missus is keen to get things back so puts a lot more effort in

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> I just turned 47 so close on your coat

Posts.Title: Can your sex life really get back to normal?

Posts.Content: gsteve A constant concern for me also, I posted a link to a very good lecture on rehabilitation in the ED thread. I am just hitting the 3 month mark and having some progress with cialis and viagra but not "stuffable" for any length of time as such. My result is heartening at the 3 month mark and I dont expect much as I do think it is going to be a 12-18 month journey to really get a handle on what to expect. My partner is very helpful in the rehabilitation so it takes some of the mntal challenge out of it which interesting enough can affect it dramatically. As the lecture outlines that adrenalin can restrict the ability to have a decent erection and this can be brought on by anxiety. I am seeing how the next few weeks go as improvements are rewarding with the tablets but I might go the injection route on my return as I have my 3 month blood test checkup

Posts.Title: Can your sex life really get back to normal?

Posts.Content: Many thanks guys, it is very early and I am still in shock to be honest, probably still going through the grief cycle. You are right the stress and anxiety about what decision to make. I am reading anything and everything to get some dimension. The surgeon seems to be dead keen on surgery and my initial thought are this is the way to go, untill I read about the side effects which are terifying to be frank. Given I am an active and fit middle aged man with a very active sex life I am trying to appreciate just how much of a lifestyle change this will mean. Will get my hands on the book you have suggested and take all the advice. If nothing else I will get my hands on all my results, talk to folk and not rush if it isnt required. I think it is very early as my DRE provided no result and prior to the biopsy both the DR and Surgeon just thought I had elevated readings and the biopsy would verify... Appreciate the response and feel I have crossed a line somewhere because everything appears a little bit different
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Greetings, My name is Bob and I am 46 and 2 days ago was told that I have prostate Cancer. This as most will already know be a bit of a shock with no history in the family and in excellent health. The initial flag went up after a routine health check the company has in place and my PSA score jumped from a consistent 2.5 over some years to 4. I subsequently had the usual anti biotics and 6 weeks later retested with a drop to 3.8. The Doctor suggested a Biopsy but also the Urine test which came back inconclusive so had to undertake the Biopsy.. seems I have a Gleason score of 7 which says I have Cancer. Yesterday went for all the scans which will go back to the Doc and I guess the options will be narrow.. Hope to learn a bit more on this forum and with any luck not feel as worried as I currently do..

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Thanks guys, nice to have some feedback with personal experience.. will get the info and see what you think.. OK the results are in GS seems to be 3+4 =7 Staging is not stated but type is Adenocarcinoma, NOS, acinar Right Apex small sections of adenocarcinoma, Gleason Score 3+3=6, present in 1 of 2 cores involving 2% of the core. There is a seperate PIN Right Mid. Sections show focal PIN in one of the cores Right Base. Nothing Left Apex . Sections show adenocarcinoma, Gleason Score 3+4=7, present in the largest of the 3 cores and involving 30% of that core Left mid. Nothing Left Base. nothing %High Grade 4/5 10% 2 cores out of 13 affected. Thats all the info I have at the moment

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hey Gang, Went to see my urologist for my 3 month results.. seems I have 0.01 result.. my Surgeon is very happy with my recovery, he was at length to tell me that my results were down to his expertise.. who am I to argue, I am in the zero club, my continence is almost returned and have useable erections for the past few weeks. I am back at the gym and my strength is rapidly returning. Work is much easier now and my days are what they were pre op. Happy days.. need to work out how to celebrate.. hang on .. Mrs Bob_R where do you think you are going...
Posts.Title: Zero Club Member

Posts.Content: Yes hope we all stay there.. I asked if there was a chance of it coming back and was told less than 2%. I used the time to chat about the journey we had gone, he was begrudging complimentary of my challenging the diagnosis, how informed I was.. I got the feeling he was used to blokes walking through the door and just agreeing to treatment. He made some interesting comments about the growth in this industry as it is big business and many surgeons are rushing to get into it and making claims of prowess. I asked how many he had done to be considered one of the top surgeons in the country, his replied 200, to which I asked why in the states if they are in the thousands how does this compare? He indicated he was watching a lot of surgeons coming through making claims of hundreds of these operations but not end to end but various stages of the procedure yet racking this up to a full operation. Also no one publishes their results in this country, there might be one or 2, and the results are largely not scientific as there is no standard of measurement for continence or erectile function.. controversial yes but probably a lot in that to consider when making statements about surgeon selection. Anyway I am pleased with progress and his belief that within the year I should be close to pre op condition. I expected him to ask to see me every 3 months but he said nope, come find him if I have an issue otherwise undertake 6 month PSA test with my GP..
Posts.Title: Zero Club Member

Posts.Content: I need this forum, I am much younger and still struggling with the concept of ED and only 2 months from surgery I should park this and know it will return but it is not like you can chat about it. Anyway Gman, really pleased to hear your good news story, keep living large
Posts.Title: 1Year Post Robotic--Life is Good!

Posts.Content: Thanks Mike, I was coming to that conclusion slowly, today was particularly bad from this perspective, however it was the least tired I have felt since the Op. Mixed blessings.. maybe tomorrow will bring a new experience Looking st your stats looks like you have had a dream run
Posts.Title: Do kegels after surgery increase the likelyhood of leakage

Posts.Content: I am now 2.5 weeks post surgery and initially told to lay off the Kegels as it would be too much strain given the recent trauma. I feel ready to go again and so this morning went through the sets the physio had provided as an intro. I would have to say that it gave me no discomfort however no where near as strong as it was pre op when I was training all the time. However I would have to say I have experienced an increased level of leakage and decreased control that i had in the first place... Is this the experience of most introducing kegels again after surgery?
Posts.Title: Do kegels after surgery increase the likelyhood of leakage

Posts.Content: Thanks Fran, you are probably right, I have a step counter and pre op I was doing 12-18 thousands steps a day which they tell me is active in the extreme, they wanted to baseline my activity levels to ensure I returned to them... I just checked todays step count and it is at 8230.. so i figure I am probably pushing myself too hard. The guilt of lying around the place is getting to me a bit.. hard to see how I am such a long way from recovery right now.

Posts.Title: PCA and Divorce

Posts.Content: Brian, Well that is indeed a great assessment, it would seem everything is contained and very much in the early stages. If your doctor is suggesting AS then it is a case of seeing i there is any aggressiveness or if indeed it just keeps at a rate that can be accommodated throughout your life. Given the results if it does move past an acceptable level for AS then you have a number of options open to you which you should investigate, surgery, seeding being the most popular. You should read up on both and weigh it against your lifestyle and suitability. But I would not stress and overthink it just now as there seems no real need to react.
Posts.Title: Just recently diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hey George, Welcome and sorry, you are in the right place and all here understand the fear and sadness which accompanies this news. I turned 47 last weekend and am 7 weeks post op after being diagnosed in August. I remember clear as day the journey and the denial followed by all the other emotions that go along with the grieving process. The reading will do your head in and because everyone is different it is hard to get a clear picture of what it means for you. The journey is not a fun one however I still believe the hardest part is trying to understand what the best treatment is for you. Given your age ( my age) I came to the conclusion after spending large wads of cash and touring to see all the specialists that really surgery is the best option for long term survival. Once you come to terms with the fact that you need to treat the cancer for life preservation the side effects become a secondary consideration important as they are. Just on the question of sex, it is different and if you are in a relationship the beginning of a new experience andyou will find from many posters here it isn't all bad you just have to be less conventional and more innovative. I have had all the nerve sparing done and given my age the expectation is I will return to my former self in time ( though at this stage it is hard to believe). Having said that the experience of orgasm is more extreme, sure like everyone else I am dry but that seems to be a plus for my other half and has made her more adventurous. Anyway I do know this is the time when it seems most frightening and you have to go on the accelerated leaning process which is overwhelming. It is tough so don't be hard on yourself regardless of the expectations you or others might have, I thought I was a corporate warrior and it knocked my confidence about a fair bit and still working it through. Keep talking and asking questions, there is a sea of knowledge and experience here to help you through.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Hey GTM Welcome, yes the first signs are disturbing and sorry you are on the this path. Given it is so early it is hard to comment where you sit in the scheme of things, although 77 is a high PSA for your age. What did the DRE reveal? The Dr has done the right thing in putting you on anti biotics to eliminate a false reading because of infection but the PSA is so high I think that even if it does bring it down you definitely need to move quickly through the steps for diagnosis. If the biopsy comes back positive then depending on the staging it will open up what your options are. At this stage there is just not enough info to comment with any confidence or provide insight. Reading all the possibilities will make you fret and the wait is going to be a while given the time it takes to get all the results. Very sorry to hear of your situation

Posts.Title: 6 week meeting with surgeon on Thursday

Posts.Content: Hey Stuart, Welcome, I don't get the sense that physio in the way you are talking is well understood in the states at this point. I am going through the process at Westmead hospital with the physio team there who specialize in this type of training. They too use the ultrasound to assist in the eduction both pre and post op. I have just returned after 4 weeks to start the recovery training. Would be very keen to see any data you have collected in respect to what the results are with and without the training regime, I think it would assist many here to understand that just 4 sets of Kegels a day is a start but a proper continence program used in conjuction with the run up to and post surgery is of great benefit. I would also recommend that there should be a nutritionist in the mix as well, I found that a walk through prior to surgery and a diet plan also immensely helpful.
Posts.Title: Continence Training

Posts.Content: Stuart, I think you are on to something with muscle memory, I am convinced that pre training has helped with my post op recovery. The challenge I have found is the amount of conflicting information which only with time has helped, this is the recording of pad use, step count and volume for bladder training. I find if I try to get my physical level up via increased step count I then suffer increased bad use and lower volume and bladder training benefit. As said it is now 4 weeks and tracking all these religiously to now get the balance. To be fair I feel there is benefit in all the training but not convinced that it accelerates the return to continence as I know folk who under took no training at all and returned within 3 weeks to continence an no issue since. I suspect I will have this issue for some time yet although I am 46, fit and had all the required training and applied it daily. Would be keen to understand more of the technical thinking behind the training.

AgeInfo.Phrase: time yet although I am 46  fit and had all the

Posts.Content: Hey Bob, welcome and wish you were not here with the rest of us. I am no expert just an experienced traveler so I will leave some of the techie answers to them, however they will ask for some more info such as your age, T level and Biopsy result. Options will be numerous given such a low score however you should look at those that you feel most comfortable with. My humble advice is to ask lots and lots of questions and read as much as you can. The initial awareness of what you should expect depending on your chosen option is going to be confronting and potentially worrisome. This is the best place to get an appreciation of where the road leads. Seems like they have found it early so prognosis is good but this depends on the other data your provide. Good to see another Bob here

Anyway I do know this is the time when it seems most frightening and you have to go on the accelerated leaning process which is overwhelming. It is tough so don't be hard on yourself regardless of the expectations you or others might have, I thought I was a corporate warrior and it knocked my confidence about a fair bit and still working it through. Keep talking and asking questions, there is a sea of knowledge and experience here to help you through.

Posts.Title: Personal note

Age.Phrase: time yet although I am 46  fit and had all the

DoctorRecommended.Sample: Would be very keen to see any data you have collected in respect to what the results are with and without the training regime, I think it would assist many here to understand that just 4 sets of Kegels a day is a start but a proper continence program used in conjuction with the run up to and post surgery is of great benefit. I would also recommend that there should be a nutritionist in the mix as well, I found that a walk through prior to surgery and a diet plan also immensely helpful....Good luck! Chuck I have read this issue seems to occur with women post Davinci Hysterectomy, they recommend you go back and see the doctor if it persists...At this point I am hating everything I am being told, so in a denial state I go and speak to other Urologists and Radio therapists, this is a good thing because it counter balances what you know and what you have been told. In the end the Radio therapist says "at your age i would recommend the surgery as the history for radio therapy is not as long as surgery and you need more years" His cut off was 50 for performing the procedure and I was just too young in his books.'...I went and saw a dietitian that was associated with the PT team at the hospital prior to surgery, she never promoted an increase in fibre just a balanced diet. But also recommended a range of foods that assist in good nutrition as well as processing.....In the end the Radio therapist says "at your age i would recommend the surgery as the history for radio therapy is not as long as surgery and you need more years" His cut off was 50 for performing the procedure and I was just too young in his books.' Now the side effects from brachy initially are much lower and invasive than surgery and you get to retain most of your function, what you need to be understanding is that longer term you have a higher potential for your continence and erectile function to be impacted given that the radioactivity first kills the disease then starts a slow demise of your prostate then potentially surrounding soft tissue....
